cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: In reference to the letter on the above sub- ject which appeared in our issue of Friday last, we do not think that our diplomats will be guilty of any discourtesy to France, nor will the "entente cordiale" between the two countries be in any way endanger- ed, if the Anglo-French Agreement is put in force without waiting for the ratification of the French Chambers, because, if our reading of French law be correct, it is quite possible that this agreement may never be submitted to them, their sanction not being necessary for its validity. Ac- The Supreme Prize Court here has annulled cording to the present Constitution of the judgment of the Vladivostok Court regard- France, the power of negotiating and ing the S.S. Allanton, mentioned on the 27th ratifying treaties is, as a general principle, June, and ordered the immediate release of vested in the hands of the President of the the vessel and cargo. Republic; but, as an exception to this principle, treaties of peace and commerce, and those which affect the finances of the State or its territorial area, can only bcome operative after being voted by the Isle of Wight this afternoon.Does the Anglo-French Agreement enter into the class of treaties covered by this attached to the suite of the Emperor William, The Russian Military attaché has been exception or not? To reply to this question and the German Military attaché to that of one would require to have a much greater the Tsar, as in the days of Alexander II. and knowledge of the details of the compact William I. This renewal of the old arrange and of French Constitutional Law than ment is regarded as indicating a close personal we lay any claim to. Anyhow it is only and political bond between the two Govern- air to suppose that our diplomats have ments, and the complete confidence of Russian not acted without knowing the views and military authorities in the friendliness of Intentions of the French Government, which will probably do its utmost to prevent a measure which is so far-reaching in its effect and which covers so much terrain brulant from being the subject of a heated party debate in the French Cham- bers. For, as was inevitable, while the principle of the agreement as a whole is accepted on both sides of the Channel with enthusiasm, there is nevertheless in both countries much opposition to its details founded on local considerations and interests. Some authorities hold that, since every treaty is liable ultimately to affect the finances of the State, the above exception practically reduces the President's power of treaty-making to a mere form and subjects the validity of all treaties to the ratification of the Chambers. This, however, is not the view the view of the French Government nor of the French Chambers themselves. It seems to be an established principle that treaties of alliance are not included amongst those. requiring the sanction of the Chambers. For instance, the treaty between Russia and France which is the basis of the alliance between the two countries has never been communicated to or ratified by the French Chambers, but nobody thinks of questioning its validity on that account. The same is the case with the Treaty of Berlin 1878, to which France was one of the signatories.

div.head: Todays Telegram
div.p: RENEWAL OF BATTLE. ST. PETERSBURG, October 22. nese have precipitately abandoned Sha-ho-pu, General Kuropatkin reports that the Japa a village situated on the south bank of the Sha-Ho, leaving a quantity of arms and ammunition. (Reuter.) LONDON, October 22. Reuter's correspondent at the Russian head- paratively inactive. They are replenishing quarters reports that both armies are com- their ammunition, there are indications of an early renewal of the battle, and that the Russians intend again to take the offensive. (Reuter.) ST. PETERSBURG, October 23. General Sakharoff reports that no serious fighting occurred yesterday. The offensive movement against the Japanese right is, apparently, not yet sufficiently developed to lead to an encounter on a large scale. The cold is very severe. The Russians are suffer- ing greatly owing to their tents being in- adequate. (Reuter.) TOKIO, October 23. (Official). The Russians are massing on the Japanese right. 200 cavalry have crossed the ing westward. THE CASUALTIES. (Reuter.) LONDON, October 23. Reuter's correspondent with General Oku reports that the casualties of the left army until the 14th inst. amount to only 5,100, of which the greater part are slightly wounded. The casualties of the Russians who opposed General Oku are estimated at the equivalent of an army corps. The Russian killed and wounded are put down by Marshal Oyama at 60,000. (Reuter.) MORE RUSSIAN RESERVES CALLED OUT. ST. PETERSBURG, October 22. service the reserves in 120 military districts, An Ukase calls out for immediate active which have hitherto been untouched. (R.) EGYPT AND THE AGREEMENT. In reference to the letter on the above sub- ject which appeared in our issue of Friday last, we do not think that our diplomats will be guilty of any discourtesy to France, nor will the "entente cordiale" between the two countries be in any way endanger- ed, if the Anglo-French Agreement is put in force without waiting for the ratification of the French Chambers, because, if our reading of French law be correct, it is quite possible that this agreement may never be submitted to them, their sanction not being necessary for its validity. Ac- The Supreme Prize Court here has annulled cording to the present Constitution of the judgment of the Vladivostok Court regard- France, the power of negotiating and ing the S.S. Allanton, mentioned on the 27th ratifying treaties is, as a general principle, June, and ordered the immediate release of vested in the hands of the President of the the vessel and cargo. Republic; but, as an exception to this principle, treaties of peace and commerce, and those which affect the finances of the State or its territorial area, can only b- THE CASE OF THE "ALLANTON." ST. PETERSBURG, October 22. (Reuter.) BALTIC FLEET STOPS STEAMER. LONDON, October 23. The Baltic fleet stopped a steamer off the come operative after being voted by the Isle of Wight this afternoon. (Reuter.) The Russian Military attaché has been exception or not? To reply to this question and the German Military attaché to that of one would require to have a much greater the Tsar, as in the days of Alexander II. and knowledge of the details of the compact William I. div.head: A SERIOUS INCIDENT. BALTIC FLEET EIRES ON THE KHEDIVE
div.p: the Danish Straits. PARIS, October 23. The Russian Squadron met a fishing flotilla from Hull in the North Sea. For reasons which are as yet unexplained it opened fire. The steamer Crane sank. Several men were wounded. (Havas.) The Russian Baltic fleet has passed through (Havas.) the Danish Straits. PARIS, October 23. The Russian Squadron met a fishing flotilla from Hull in the North Sea. For reasons which are as yet unexplained it opened fire. The steamer Crane sank. Several men were wounded. (Havas.) day afternoon. KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY. The Egyptian Government intend giving the Khedivial Agricultural Society a larger basis to enable it to extend its operations. subvention and will organise it on a broader The nature of the measures to be undertaken is still under discussion. GREEK ENTERPRISE IN THE RED SEA. A new local steam navigation company has been founded under Hellenic auspices for trading between Suez and the Red Sea ports.. The steamers will visit regularly the ports of Jeddah, Sheikh el-Bargout, Hodeidah, and Aden from Suez, and will make the return voyage in the same order. The title of the new company will be "The Hellenic Commer- DOVER, October 23. The Baltic fleet passed here this afternoon going westwards. It is rumoured that they ran down and sank two Hull fishing smacks in the North Sea, drowning 18 fishermen. (Reuter.)cial Steam Navigation Company of the Red LONDON, October 23. The solicitors for, the owners of 50 Hull trawlers have notified the Foreign Office and Admiralty that an attack was made upon the boats by the Baltic Fleet. They state that the first portion of the Baltic fleet passed the fishing ground at midnight on Friday. The remainder, however, turned their search-lights on the British trawlers for some time, and then opened fire, the trawler Crane being sunk. The decapitated bodies of the skipper and mate were brought to Hull. The boatswain and others who were wounded are now on board the mission ship. The trawlers Moulmein and Mino have arrived at Hull seriously damaged. The latter has 16 shot holes. It is feared that another trawler has been sunk with all on board. (Reuter.) HULL, October 23. The fleet of trawlers has arrived here. They report that the Baltic fleet on Friday night attacked them in the North Sea, and sank two, Two men were killed and many wounded

div.head: FRANCE AND THE VATICAN
div.p: DEBATE IN THE FRENCH CHAMBER

. CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.-M. Combes recalled the attacks of the clergy against the Republic. He said that the Vatican repelled the pre- ponderance of the civil power. M. Combes wanted the liberty of the church, which was measure compatible with other liberties. M. Ribot opposed the separation of Church from State. He left the responsibility for it to the Government. M. Combes put the question of confidence. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence by 325 votes against 257.

CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES. During the debate on the religious policy of the Government, M. Combes declared that, in view of the Vatican's open disregard for the Concordat, the separa- tion of Church and State had become inevit- able. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence in the Government by 325 to 237 votes. (R.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: A PARADE of the British Garrison of Cairo will be held at Kasr-el-Nil on the 27th inst. at
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Boulac district of Cairo during to-night and at the Mousky during to-morrow night will be poisoned by the police.
CHRYSANTHEMUM SHOW. The Alexandria Horticultural Society's annual Chrysanthemum Show will be held at the San Stefano Casino on Saturday and Sunday next.

PORT SAID-ISMAILIA LINE. The prepara- tions which have been made for the official inauguration by the Khedive of the Port Said- Ismailia railway line have been countermanded as the ceremony is not to take place.

HASHISH SEIZURE. The Customs Guards seized 220 kilos of hashish on board the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Amphitrate on Saturday. The drug was concealed in two parcels of lug- gage and 3 oil tins. The owner has not been found.

VICTORIA COLLEGE.-The number of boys at Victoria College has now reached over one The London Stock Exchange Committee ha hundred, fifty of whom are new entries this appointed a special settling day as under term. The road facing the sea is to be completed Anglo-Egyptian Bank, further issue of 20,000 shortly, and this will be very convenient for shares of £15 each, £5 paid, Nos. 80,001 to pupils and their friends visiting the College.

SUEZ CANAL. On the 20th inst. 15 vessels Official List: Anglo-Egyptian Bank, furthe passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 10 issue of 20,000 shares of £15 each, £5 paid were British, 1 Dutch, 1 German, 1 Austrian, Nos. 80,001 to 100,000. 1 Russian, and 1 Spanish. The transit and pas- 'senger dues for the day amounted to 444,540.58 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the first to that date on 255 The Highland Light Infantry left Cair vessels amounted to 6,603,396.24 frs.

EIRE AT ALEXANDRIA.-A fire broke out last evening in a chair factory in Saleh el-Din- street belonging to Messrs. Abraham. and them farewell. Mattatia. The Alexandria Fire Brigade arrived at about 8 p.m. and the fire was not entirely extinguished until 11.30 p.m. The factory was gutted, the Brigade finally confining itself to saving the surrounding buildings. The origin of the fire has not yet been ascertained. The losses are stated to be covered by insurance,

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is to-day at Mariout. Djellal el-Din Pasha was received in audience by his Highness at Montazah on Saturday afternoon.

div.head: Khedival Agricultural Society
div.p: The Egyptian Government intend giving the Khedivial Agricultural Society a larger basis to enable it to extend its operations. subvention and will organise it on a broader The nature of the measures to be undertaken is still under discussion.

div.head: The Garstin Report
div.p: By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., late In- speetor-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt (Coutinued.)

Sir W. Willeocks' basis of caleulstion of the supply required is that a stored quantity of one millised of cuble metres of water is suffi- clent fur the conversion of 300,000 acres to pereanial irrigation; and also that, after tak ing into account the milliard already provided by the Assonsn Reserroir, there still remain 1j million aetes to be converted. Three mil liand eubie metres more are, therefore, accord- ing bo has figures, required. One milliard is to be poovided by mising the Assouan Dam 6 m pooposal already diseuseed as the first item of Sir W. Gantin's programime. The remaining two milliards Sir W. Willeocks proposes to roovide by storage in the Wadi Rayan, deprression in the Libyan Desert to the south of the Fayoum, from which it is separated by a lmestone ridge. The depression has, at a leve of about 29 m. abore the ses, a surfsce of 700 equare kilometres, about a quarter of the size of the ancient Lako Moeris. The lowent point of the Wadi is 81 m. below sea-level. 1f Siled with water from the Nile to make i serve as, a reservoir, it will be the top layer only of a few metres' depth that will be utilised to supplement the summer Nile. The proposal t make the Wadi Rayan a reservoir waa Mr. Cop W hitehogse's original conoeptiom;but, originally conceived as an isolated project, ita weak point was that by itself it wonld give a plentiful dis chatge in Apeil and May, less in June, and very little in July, whereas what is wanted i the roverse. Sir W. Willeoeks has now pointed ous that "whem the Asequan Reservoir i capable.of supplying two milliands of eubie metres of frater it will be possible to utilise the Moeris Lake to its atmost capacity. The As souan Reservoir, being high above the level o the Nile, can give its stipply at the beginning or end of the summer: it can give it slowly, or with a rueh, while the projeeted Lak Moeris, being directly in communiention with the Nile, and only slightly above low Nile level, its discharge would depend entirely on th ditferenee of level between it and the Nile, and coseyuently as the entier advanced it would gridually fall, and would not be able to giv at the end of the suminer a quarter of the di charge it could give at the beginning. But us imagine that the reservoir and the lake are both completed, and full of water, and that it is the first of April. Lake Moeris - ie, th Rayan Beservoir-will be opened into the Nile and give all the water peeded in that month while the Assouan Reeervoir will be maintaine at its full level. In May, Lake Moeris will gi yearly the whole sapply and the roservoir wil give a little. In June the lake will giye littl and the reservoir much; while im July the lake will givo practically nothing and the reservoir the whole supply. Working together in thi hanonious manher, the reservoir and the lake which are the true complements of each othe will easily provide the whole of the wate heeded for Egypt." Sir W. Garstin concodes that the schem thus presented is a most attrnetive one. T foejeet of reviving the ancient Lake Moeris i a neighhouring depressioa to that which onc hell the clawical lake has fascinated many tnongst others Sir W. Willoocks ; hence th neressity for withholding judgment on th houject antil its weak poiuts have been examin ed lest its outside personal attractions shoul cbtain for it the approvnl that it mny n doerve. The depression would be flled by einnl connecting it with the Nile acroes 2 kikms. of the ealtivated land of the Ben Snef Province and 16 kiloma, of deser an it weuld take three and a-b o seven yoars to fill, according to differe e-timates, before it began its funetions a reservoir to supplement the low Nile. Aft that it woul receive its aunnal recoupmen necoeding to one of Sir W. Willoocks' proposal during flood, and, according to the oth during flood and winter. (To be continned.)

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: A. 8. C. 8KYE MEETING.

Saturday's race meeting was dull and uninteresting, the only notable feature of the afternoon being the entirely unexpected win of Valentino in the race for the San Stefano Plate, when he brought off a 45 to 1 chance. In this race, the riding of Michaelides Jun. was considered unsatisfactory, and he was therefore suspended by the stewards until the end of the year. There was a good deal of betting and the odds in most cases were sufficiently attractive. P.T. 1,300 for a dollar, which was netted by each of the four backers of Valentino, is probably a record for the A.S.C. course. The ground, owing to the rain, was not conducive to fast riding, as the horses skidded a great deal. Owing to the uncertainty which prevailed as regards the elements, a large number of race-goers absented themselves from the meeting, with the consequence that the attendance was exceedingly poor, which added to the dulness of the after- noon, relieved only by the excellent playing of the Royal Berkshire Band under the leader- ship of Bandmaster Dore. The following were the resulta of the various races :-- MAIDEN HURDLE RACE of P.T. 1,250 of which P.T. 250 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arabs. Weight for age, ponies allow- ed 7 lbs. Distance round the course over 7 flights. Moh. Pasha Chehim's g.a.h. Mizzaud 10.4 Hassan. Mr. Bustros' ch.a.h. Malgre Tout, 10.7 Fen- wick. Ibrahim Bey Cherif'sg.a.h. Mouchir, 10.7 Elias.0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif and Elie Bey Sursock's g.a.h. Arabi, 10.7 Bonser. Malgre Tout came over the last hurdle first, slightly ahead of Mizzaud, who, however, caught him up and won by about t a length, 2 lengths dividing 2nd and 3rd.Betting .- Totalizator paid P.T. 39 on winner and P.T. 41 and 32 respectively for places. PONY PLATE of P.T. 2,500 of which P.T, 500 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches. Previous winners of any race of advertised value of P.T. 5,000 or more to carry 7lbs. for one win, 10lbs. for two, 14lbs for 3 or more wins, Distance 5 furlongs. Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Loulou, 10.1. Jenkins. Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Ruy Blas, 10.7. Hassan. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.p. Sattam, 10.1. Eliseo. Ishak Bey Hussein's ch.a.p. Abou Senoun, 10.8. Aly Farag. Elie Bey Sursock's g.a.p. Nimr, 10.3. Tannous. 0 Mr. M.Tueni's b.a.p. Viking, 10.10. Matthews. 0 Mohar. Pasha Chehim's ch.a.p. Vali, 9.13. Mr: A. J. Michaelides. Ishak Bey Hussein, and Hassan Bey Kheir-el- Din's b.a.p. Faik, 10.7. Stillwell. Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Ilaros, 9.11. Vassili. 0 Mr. Jaoques Chalom's g.a.p. Fahr, 10.8. Fenwick. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's c.a.p. Jean, 10.7. Mi- chaelides Jun. Viking and Faik jumped off from a badstart and made the running until they came out of the cutting, followed by Ruy Blas, when Loulou came to the front and won a good race from the latter by a neck. This was a very fast race considering the condition of the ground. Time-1.10. Betting .- Totalizator paid P.T. 102 on wintier, and P.T. 58, 150, and 150 respectively for places. GALLOWAY STAKES of P.T. 2,500 of which P.T. 500 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab galloways. Weight for age and inches. Distance one mile. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's b.a.p. St .- Frusquin, 9.13. Michaelides Jun. Mr. A. J. Sursock's b.a.p. Sans Pareil, 10.1. Hassan. Baron J. E. de Menasce's ch.a.h. Radium. 10.3. Matthews. Mr. N. Soussa's g.a.p. Habashi, 10.11. Kamel Effendi. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's g.a.h. Kohailan, 9.13. Moh. Bastawissi. Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Royal Oak, 9.6. Vassili. Habashi declared 3 lb. overweight and Sans Pareil 1 lb. Sans Pareil and St. Frusquin were the first to emerge from the cutting, the others being in a bunch behind. The two mounte maintained their position in the straight and the latter won by about a head, after a close struggle be- tween the pair. Radium was a bad third.

div.head: Selling Race
div.p: of P.T, 1,250 of which P.T. 250 to go to 2nd horse. For Arabs. Winner to be sold by auction for P.T. 5,000. 7 lbs allowed for every P.T. 1,000 less than that price. Top weight 11.0. Galloways 10.10. Ponies 10.7. Distance mile. Ishak Bey Hussein's and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's g.a.h. El.Amal, (P.T. 3000). 10.1. 1 Mr. J. N. Simonds' b.a.p. The Bard, (late Lucky dog): (P.T. 3000), 9.7. Whiteside. Mr. M. Tueni's ch.a.h. Falcon, (P.T. 4000). 10.3. Matthews. Mr: N. Soussa's ch.a.p. Avenir, (P.T. 4000). 10.0. Hassan. El Amal got away from a good start and came out of the cutting a length in front of the rest of the field. In the straight Bard, who is a new horse with a future, came away with a rush and lost first place by only a short head. A length divided 2nd and 3rd. Time 1.28. SAN STEFANO PLATE of P.T. 2,500 of which P.T. 500 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arabs. Weight for age. Distance round the coufse. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's b.a.h. Valentino, 10.1 Elias. Ibrahim Bey Cherif and Elie Bey Sursock's b.a.h. Mikado, 10.0 Michaelides Jun. Ishak Bey Hussein's, ch.a.h. El Tahawi, 10.0 Stillwell. Mr. E. Boutros' g.a.h. Don Quichotte, 8.13. Mabmoud. Mr. E. Karam's g.a.h. Perth, 10. Mikhali. Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun's b.a.h. Dahman, 10.7. Moh. Bastawissi. Mr. M.Tueni's b.a.p. Caprice, 10.7. Matthews. 0 Mr. A.J. Sursock's g.a.p. Boule de Neige, 10.1. Hassan. The whole field, with the exception of Caprice, was despatched to a good start, Caprice being left at the post. Valentino made most of the running, followed by Mikado and El Tahawi, this order being maintained all through the race, which was won by about a length, 2 lengths separating 2nd and 3rd. Time -- 2.37. Totalizator paid P.T. 1,300 on winner and P.T. 97,28, and 22 respectively for places. SUBSTITUTION PLATE of P.T. 2,500 of 2 3 0 1 2 3 0
